questions.title: A Difficult Decision You Had to Make
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Difficult Decision You Had to Make'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have faced a moment when they had to choose between things they love. I remember a time when I had to make a very difficult decision about my music classes. It taught me about managing time and making tough choices.

It was during the middle of the school year. I was learning many things - Carnatic vocal, Hindustani vocal, mridangam, and tabla. Tabla was special because it complemented my mridangam learning. Together, they helped me understand both the rhythm systems of Indian classical music - the Carnatic and the Hindustani traditions.

I enjoyed going to tabla class every week. My teacher was kind, and I was improving. The catch was that school work was getting tougher. I had exams, projects, and homework. I also had to practice Carnatic vocal, Hindustani vocal, and mridangam regularly. There were only so many hours in a day. I was tired and could not give my best to anything.

After thinking for many days, I made my choice. Even though I liked tabla very much, I decided not to continue with it. It was sad, but I knew I could not do everything well. I told my tabla teacher, and he understood. He said I could come back anytime in the future.

This experience taught me that sometimes we have to let go of good things to focus on what matters most. I learned that it is better to do fewer things well than many things poorly. I will always remember what I learned in tabla, and I won't regret making that difficult choice.

questions.title: A Hot Summer Day
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Hot Summer Day'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a day when the heat was so strong that it felt like the sun was burning everything. I remember one such day during our desert safari in Dubai. It showed me how powerful the sun can be.

It was the end of May when we went on our family trip to Dubai. The sun was very bright, and there was no cloud cover at all. Dubai has very little pollution, so the sunlight came directly without anything blocking it. It felt like the sun was literally burning our skin whenever we stepped outside.

Indoors, everything was fine because of the air conditioning. The malls, hotels, and cars were all cool and comfortable. We decided to go for a desert safari in the evening, thinking it would be cooler. The catch was that even in the evening, the desert had no shade and no air conditioning. The sand was hot, and the air felt like it came from an oven. We could still feel the heat pressing down on us.

We rode in special cars over the sand dunes. The drivers were skilled and made the ride exciting. We watched the sunset, which painted the desert in orange and red colors. Later, we had dinner at a camp with traditional Arabic food. By night, the temperature finally dropped, and we enjoyed the cool desert breeze under the stars.

This experience taught me how people in desert regions live with such extreme heat. I learned that the sun's power is very strong when there is no pollution or clouds to filter it. I will always respect people who work outdoors in hot places, and I won't complain about Chennai's heat after experiencing the Dubai desert.

questions.title: A Time of Unexpected Kindness
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Time of Unexpected Kindness'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a moment when someone helped them without expecting anything in return. I remember one such time when a friend showed me unexpected kindness. It made me believe in true friendship.

It was during my uncle's marriage. I had to go on leave and miss two days of school because of the wedding. The marriage was in another city, and my whole family attended. We had a wonderful time celebrating, but I kept thinking about the classwork I was missing.

When I came back to school, I was worried. I needed to copy the notes from those two days. I asked a few classmates, but everyone was busy with their own work. Some said they would give later, but later never came. The catch was that the exams were coming soon, and I was falling behind. I did not know what to do.

Then my friend Janina came to me. Without me even asking, she offered to share her notes. She had neat handwriting and had written everything clearly. She even sat with me during lunch break and explained the difficult parts. She did not ask for anything in return. She simply said, "That's what friends do."

This experience taught me that true friends help without being asked. I learned that kindness means noticing when someone needs help and acting on it. I will always remember Janina's kindness, and I won't hesitate to help my friends when they need me.

questions.title: A Visit to the Doctor
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Visit to the Doctor'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have visited a doctor when they were sick. I remember one such visit to my paediatrician when I was very unwell. It reminded me how important it is to have a good doctor who knows you.

It was a week when I fell very sick. I had high fever that would not go down. I also had a bad cold and cough. My nose was blocked, my throat was sore, and I felt weak all over. My parents decided to take me to Dr. Benny Benjamin, my paediatrician.

Dr. Benny Benjamin has been my doctor since I was a baby. He knows me very well. When we reached his clinic, he checked my temperature, looked at my throat, and listened to my chest with his stethoscope. The catch was that my fever was quite high, and he was concerned. But he knew exactly what to do because he had treated me many times before.

Dr. Benjamin knows which medicines work for me and which do not. He prescribed the right antibiotics and syrups. He told my parents how to take care of me at home. He also asked them to bring me back if the fever did not go down in two days. Within a few days of taking his medicines, I started feeling much better.

This experience taught me how lucky I am to have a doctor who knows me since childhood. I learned that a good doctor understands your body and your history. I will always be grateful to Dr. Benny Benjamin for taking care of me, and I won't take good health for granted.

questions.title: A Visit to the Seaside
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Visit to the Seaside'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have a special memory of visiting the sea with their family. I remember our trip to Mahabalipuram as a joint family. It was a weekend filled with the sea, temples, and togetherness.

It was a long weekend when our whole joint family decided to go to Mahabalipuram. We stayed at a resort called Chariot Beach Resort. The resort was beautiful, and from our rooms, we could hear the sound of the waves. They served many different kinds of cuisines - South Indian, North Indian, Chinese, and Continental.

During the day, we visited the famous heritage sites of Mahabalipuram. We saw the Shore Temple, which is very old and stands right next to the sea. We visited the Arjuna's Penance, a huge rock carving that tells stories from our mythology. The catch was that walking in the sun was tiring, but the history and beauty of these ancient places made it worth it. Our elders told us stories about each monument.

The best part was spending time at the beach. The sea at Mahabalipuram is beautiful. The waves came rolling in, one after another, making a soothing sound. The water was blue and stretched as far as I could see. We collected seashells, built sandcastles, and let the waves touch our feet. In the evening, the sunset turned the sky orange and pink, and the sea reflected those colors. It was like a painting.

This experience taught me the joy of traveling with family and learning about our heritage. I learned that the sea has a calming power that makes you feel peaceful. I will always remember the sound of the waves at Mahabalipuram, and I won't forget the stories my grandparents told me about the temples.

questions.title: When I Met with an Accident
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'When I Met with an Accident'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a moment that happened so fast they could not stop it. I remember an accident that happened when I was very young. It left burns on my body and taught my family to be more careful.

It was an ordinary day at home. My grandmother had boiled milk and kept it on a low table to cool down. The milk was still very hot. I was a small child then, running around the house playing. I did not notice the container of hot milk in my path.

I was running fast and did not see where I was going. The catch was that I accidentally hit the container and it spilled all over me. The boiling hot milk fell on the front of my body. I screamed in pain. There were burns all over my chest and stomach. My parents heard me crying and came running. They were shocked to see what had happened.

My parents acted quickly. They rushed me to Malar Hospital in Adyar. The doctors there treated my burns carefully. It was painful, and I had to be very careful for many weeks while the burns healed. My family took great care of me during that time. The doctors at Malar Hospital did a good job, and slowly I recovered.

This experience taught me how quickly accidents can happen, especially with hot things. I learned that we must always be careful around hot liquids and keep them away from where children play. I will always be alert about safety in the kitchen, and I won't forget to keep hot things out of reach of small children.

questions.title: When I Witnessed an Accident
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'When I Witnessed an Accident'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have witnessed something unexpected that surprised them. I remember the time when I was in our car and another vehicle hit us from behind. It taught me about accidents and how people react to them.

It was a regular day, and we were driving on Chamiers Road in Chennai. Our driver Selva was driving carefully as usual. The road was busy with many vehicles. I was sitting in the back seat, looking out the window.

Suddenly, there was a loud bang from behind. A vehicle had come fast and hit the back of our car. Our car shook, and I was startled. The catch was that the other driver had not been paying attention and had crashed into us. Thankfully, no one was hurt badly, but our car had a dent.

Our driver Selva got very angry. He jumped out of the car and started fighting with the driver of the other vehicle. They were shouting at each other and blaming one another. Other people on the road gathered to watch. My parents had to calm Selva down and handle the situation. They exchanged phone numbers with the other driver and decided to sort it out later.

This experience taught me that accidents can happen even when you are driving carefully. I learned that getting angry does not solve problems, but staying calm helps. I will always remember to stay calm in difficult situations, and I won't let anger make things worse.

questions.title: A Day When the Lights Went Off
questions.question: Write a narrative essay on 'A Day When the Lights Went Off'.
paragraphs: Everyone would have experienced a power cut that made them realize how much we depend on electricity. I remember a night when the lights went off during a cyclone in Chennai. It taught me to appreciate the simple things we take for granted.

It was the month of December, and Chennai was hit by a cyclone. Heavy rains were pouring down, and the wind was howling outside. We were all at home, hoping the storm would pass soon. Then, suddenly, all the lights went off.

The house became pitch dark. I could not see anything around me - not the furniture, not even my own hand in front of my face. The catch was that it was night time, and without the street lights outside, there was no light at all. But I could hear the rain clearly. The sound of raindrops hitting the roof and windows was loud. I could even smell the rain - that fresh, earthy smell that comes with heavy showers.

We waited in the darkness, hoping the power would come back. It took some time for our watchman to go to the generator room and switch on our building's generator. Once he did, the lights came back on in our house. We all felt relieved. We could finally see again and move around safely. We could only sleep peacefully after the generator was switched on.

This experience taught me how much we depend on electricity for everything. I learned that our senses become sharper in darkness - I heard and smelled things I usually ignore. I will always be grateful for the simple comfort of having lights, and I won't forget to thank people like our watchman who help during emergencies.
